questions.question: A 10-year-old has been on strict bedrest for 9 days after a spinal injury. Which complication of immobilization are you most directly trying to prevent with regular active and passive range-of-motion exercises?
options: Increased bone density
Enhanced cardiac output
Contractures and joint stiffness
Improved fine motor coordination

questions.question: A 6-year-old in a long-leg cast after a femur fracture suddenly complains of severe pain in the casted leg. The leg looks pale and feels cool; the child refuses to move the toes. What is the priority action?
options: Notify the provider immediately to assess for compartment syndrome
Elevate the leg on pillows and reassess in 30 minutes
Offer distraction and non-pharmacologic pain measures
Apply a warm pack to improve local circulation

questions.question: A 7-year-old presents with an acutely swollen, painful ankle after a soccer injury. An X-ray shows no fracture. Which initial management is most appropriate?
options: Apply a warm moist compress and encourage early weight bearing
Begin active range-of-motion exercises within 30 minutes of injury
Splint the ankle only if the pain persists beyond 24 hours
Use protection, rest, ice, compression, and elevation of the ankle

questions.question: When comparing fractures in children versus adults, which statement is most accurate?
options: Children’s bones heal more slowly because of their open growth plates
Children have a thicker periosteum, leading to more rapid bone healing
Children’s bones are less vascular, so they are at lower risk for infection
Children rarely experience greenstick fractures due to bone flexibility

questions.question: A 3-year-old in a hip spica cast is being discharged. Which home care teaching is most important to emphasize to the parents?
options: Use talcum powder inside the cast to keep the skin dry
Loosen the cast with a hairdryer on cool if the child is uncomfortable
Protect the cast from urine and stool with careful diapering and check the skin frequently
Remove the cast briefly each day to inspect the underlying skin

questions.question: A child with suspected osteomyelitis of the femur is admitted. Which assessment finding is most consistent with acute osteomyelitis?
options: Painless limb with full range of motion and normal temperature
Generalized pruritus and scleral jaundice
Petechiae over the extremities with mucosal bleeding
Localized bone pain, warmth over the site, fever, and irritability

questions.question: The plan of care for a child with osteomyelitis includes long-term antimicrobial therapy. Which nursing action is most appropriate?
options: Encourage full weight bearing to promote bone healing as soon as pain decreases
Administer IV antibiotics via a PICC line and monitor renal and hepatic function
Switch to oral antibiotics as soon as the child’s pain is controlled
Discontinue antibiotics once the child has been afebrile for 24 hours

questions.question: A 12-year-old with scoliosis has been prescribed a thoracolumbosacral orthosis (TLSO) brace. Which teaching point best promotes treatment effectiveness?
options: Wear the brace as prescribed each day and continue normal school and social activities
Wear the brace only when back pain becomes severe
Remove the brace whenever you are sitting to prevent pressure areas
Expect the brace to permanently cure your scoliosis without further follow-up

questions.question: A 10-year-old is scheduled for spinal fusion with instrumentation for severe scoliosis. In the immediate postoperative period, which assessment is the priority?
options: Oral intake and return of bowel sounds
Pain level and need for additional opioids
Ability to sit unsupported at the bedside
Neurovascular checks of the lower extremities and monitoring respiratory status

questions.question: A child with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is starting on a treatment regimen that includes NSAIDs and possibly methotrexate. What is the primary overall goal of therapy?
options: Cure the disease and prevent any recurrence of joint symptoms
Control pain, preserve joint function, and promote normal growth and development
Restrict activity to minimize fatigue and protect joints from further injury
Avoid medications altogether to prevent long-term adverse effects

questions.question: The nurse teaches parents of a child with JIA about home care. Which statement indicates correct understanding?
options: “We’ll encourage regular exercise, use warm baths, and keep splints on as prescribed.”
“We’ll avoid all heat and use only ice packs when the joints hurt.”
“We’ll stop the medications as soon as she seems better for a few days.”
“We’ll keep her in bed as much as possible to protect her joints.”

questions.question: A 9-month-old infant is being evaluated for possible cerebral palsy. Which finding is most concerning?
options: Startle response with loud noises
Stranger anxiety and crying when separated from parents
Persistent head lag and clenched fists beyond 4 months of age
Ability to sit unsupported and transfer objects hand to hand

questions.question: When explaining cerebral palsy (CP) to parents, which description is most accurate?
options: “It is a progressive muscle disease that will steadily worsen over time.”
“It is a nonprogressive motor disorder caused by a lesion or anomaly in the developing brain.”
“It is an autoimmune disease that causes intermittent episodes of paralysis.”
“It always causes severe intellectual disability that cannot be improved.”

questions.question: A newborn is diagnosed with a myelomeningocele in the lumbosacral area. Before surgical repair, which nursing intervention has the highest priority?
options: Place the infant in a supine position to optimize airway management
Apply a dry dressing to the sac and leave it open to air to promote drying
Begin vigorous passive range-of-motion exercises of the lower extremities
Position the infant prone with hips slightly flexed and cover the sac with moist, sterile dressings

questions.question: The nurse caring for an infant with myelomeningocele includes latex precautions in the plan of care. What is the best rationale?
options: Latex is never used in pediatric care because it always causes skin breakdown
Only infants with a positive skin test for latex allergy require latex precautions
Children with myelomeningocele have a high risk of developing severe latex allergy from repeated early exposure
Latex precautions are necessary only if the child has a family history of atopy or asthma

questions.question: A 4-year-old boy is being evaluated for Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Which finding is most characteristic of DMD?
options: Waddling gait, frequent falls, and using hands to “walk up” the thighs to stand
Spasticity and scissoring of the legs during walking
Intention tremor with ataxic gait and nystagmus
Sudden onset of flaccid paralysis and loss of all reflexes

questions.question: The primary goal of therapy for a child with Duchenne muscular dystrophy is to:
options: Reverse muscle degeneration with high-dose corticosteroids
Prevent all physical activity to protect remaining muscle fibers
Achieve complete cure through early orthopedic surgery
Maintain function in unaffected muscles and keep the child active as long as possible

questions.question: A nurse is planning care for a child with spastic cerebral palsy that affects mobility. Which intervention best supports mobility and function?
options: Encouraging complete bedrest with only passive range of motion
Avoiding orthotics or splints to reduce the risk of pressure injuries
Using physical therapy, assistive devices, and stretching to maximize independence
Withholding activities that require energy expenditure to minimize fatigue

questions.question: A 9-year-old child is newly admitted with a femur fracture and is placed in skeletal traction. Which nursing action is most appropriate?
options: Place the traction weights on the bed when the child complains of pain
Ensure the weights hang freely and maintain proper body alignment
Allow the child to adjust the ropes and pulleys for comfort
Remove the weights briefly during bathing and toileting

questions.question: A nurse is caring for several immobilized children on the unit. Which intervention is most appropriate to prevent venous stasis and venous thromboembolism (VTE)?
options: Apply anti-embolic stockings and encourage active movement of unaffected limbs
Restrict oral fluids to prevent edema and fluid overload
Elevate only the head of the bed to 90 degrees at all times
Massage the calves firmly to improve venous return
